items.title: A Hiring Manager's Perspective on Your Portfolio
items.content:
Consider your audience

Just like you would when designing a product or experience for your end-user, consider the audience for your portfolio website. Recruiters, hiring managers, and hiring committees have unique goals and pain points that you must consider.

Consider the following when designing for the person you want to impress:

Time

Hiring managers and recruiters often review 10-20 portfolios in one sitting. Recruiters in particular tend to spend 3 minutes or less reviewing each portfolio–just long enough to determine whether they should spend more time with you as a candidate.

Below is a baseline hiring manager checklist criteria. Have you answered these questions for the hiring manager concisely and effectively with your case study and portfolio?

  • Can the designer research?
  • Can the designer synthesize?
  • Can the designer deliver visually consistent deliverables?
  • Can the designer show rationale for visual design decisions?
  • Can the designer think, ideate, and problem solve?
  • Can the designer validate with testing?
  • Can the designer express all of the above in a concise, direct manner?

Context

Once you reach a later hiring stage, you might be asked to talk your way through a case study. However, consider the first impression your portfolio makes when a recruiter or HR person stumbles across it alone the first time.

Format

While a personal portfolio website is a common medium for delivering your design portfolio, additional options include Dribbble, Behance, slide decks, or creating a case study on a Medium blog.

Shape your content

UX designers are sometimes in danger of telling too much in a case study because of the complexity of the design process. There may need to be some details consolidated or removed to make the story feel like it flows well to the reader. Remember, when in doubt, keep it simple and easy to digest. Shorter is always better.

UI designers are often in danger of showing too much and writing too little on their design thinking. If you did any concepting on branding, show the multiple ideas and visual directions you designed and why you landed on those concepts. Show adaptability in your visual design and user interaction skills and work. Lead with your visuals, but don’t underestimate your supporting copy.

Highlight your contribution

Your ability to work well and collaborate with others is key to your success in your next job. Anything you share about your journey should include key moments of teamwork while still highlighting your contribution to the particular project.

Please don’t be shy to give credit where it’s due. For example, call out if another team member produced motion graphics for your video content. You can then mention that you managed the production of the video and helped with the storyboarding.

Being honest about your work and showing a thirst to learn more are appealing qualities to a hiring manager. Speak honestly about some of the challenges you faced. Your story should include unexpected challenges in a professional environment and how you overcame them. This includes moments you encountered:

  • Difficulty communicating with stakeholder
  • Negative feedback from the team or the users
  • Pivoting when your solution did not test well

Highlight these things that show self-awareness, accountability, and resilience.

Confidentiality

Check with your client and ensure you can show your work publicly.

If the status of a particular project means you need to password protect your work, that shouldn’t bother the hiring manager. However, make sure to make things easier for the hiring manager by including the password when contacting them.

items.title: Parts of a Case Study
items.content:
What is a case study?

A case study examines a project you have worked on as a designer.

It demonstrates your design process from start to finish in the form of a compelling story.

What belongs in a case study?

At its simplest, a case study consists of four parts:

  1. Overview. Introduce the project and provide context.
  2. Background. What problem were you trying to solve?
  3. Process. What kind of journey did your project go on?
  4. Outcome. What were the final results of your project? What did you learn?

Overview

Since your case study is aimed at recruiters and hiring managers who are short on time, it’s helpful to provide an overview of the project up front.

The overview is a way to share, at a glance, the most basic details of the project, along with a compelling and representative graphic showcasing the solution.

The project overview might include the following:

  • Client or project name. If the client’s brand is not well known, you might optionally include a brief description of the company or a link out to the company website.
  • Your role. You might additionally use this space to briefly mention contributions from team members.
  • Summary. This is typically a two or three-sentence description of the problem, the process, and the solution and/or outcomes.
  • Deliverables.
  • Tools. Both digital and analogue.
  • Project length (optional). How long did the project take from start to finish? How many sprints?

These brief high-level overviews of the project at the beginning of a full case study make it very scannable and digestible. The overview keeps your viewer from having to struggle to find the name of the project, your role, and key takeaways.

Background

While the specifics of your project background might vary depending on the nature of the project, Sarah Doody of Career Strategy Lab recommends at least the following details:

Problem statement

  • What challenge were you presented with?
  • Why did this project need to happen?
  • What was the project goal or desired outcome?

Users & target audience

  • Who was the user?
  • What did you know about their habits? Their needs?

Scope & constraints

  • Did you face any limitations?
  • What was the project timeline?
  • Were there budgetary constraints?

Process

The process section is where you document the design process your project went through.

In the words of Sarah Doody, the process section of a case study should answer the following questions.

  • What did you do? For example, what research method did you use?
  • Why did you do it? For example, why did you choose that research method?
  • What was the result? For example, did you achieve your research goals?
  • What did you learn? For example, what would you do differently next time?

While your case study is meant to tell a compelling story from start to finish, your story won’t necessarily be a linear one. The design process is an iterative one, so don’t skip over moments where a hypothesis was invalidated and your team needed to revisit an earlier stage.

”Bear in mind that the focus here is on the process, so emphasis on iterations, rising challenges, alternatives, decision points and conflict resolution is paramount.” – Andreas Komninos, How to create the perfect structure for a UX case study

Outcomes

The outcome of your case study might include the final solution to the project. We say might because some case studies prefer to capture user attention by including the final deliverables as part of the overview.

If you haven’t showcased the final product yet, be sure to do so in the outcomes section. To otherwise create a lasting final impression, make sure your outcomes include the following:

Impact

Connect the work you did back to the original goals of the project and the problem you were trying to solve. If you have metrics demonstrating the impact of your work, highlight them here.

Next steps

Where should this project go next? What recommendations do you have for future improvements?

Reflections

According to Teo Yu Siang of Interaction Design Foundation, if you’re struggling to put what you learned from this project into words, here are some questions you can ask yourself:

  • What was your main challenge in this project, and how did you handle it?
  • What are some lessons you learned from the project?
  • How has the project changed your outlook as a designer?

Examples

  • Crystal Ma
  • Caitlin Brisson
  • Angela Kung
  • Jihoon Suh
  • Kyle Skidmore

items.title: UX Writing
items.content:
What is UX writing?

“UX writing is the practice of writing carefully considered information that addresses people’s contexts, needs, and behaviors. Writing copy involves many of the same skills as visual or interaction design, except writers use words instead of pixels to communicate with users throughout the experience.” – Anna Kaley, Nielsen Norman Group

UX writers work to make each task a user needs to complete while using a product as simple and as uncomplicated as possible.

Unlike a marketing writer, who joins a project once an active or upcoming product needs promoting, UX writers are present at numerous stages during the design process, including user research and testing sessions.

UX writers are responsible for both content writing and microcopy (interface labels, error messaging, hints guiding users on what actions to take). UX writers also help establish the brand voice for a company or product, and may create documentation advising how to apply this voice across a variety of products, services, and use cases.

Why is UX writing important?

UX writing improves the functionality, usability, and accessibility of a product.

At its best, UX writing empathizes with users, clarifies uncertainties and humanizes a digital product, while at the same time reassuring users that they’re making progress towards a goal.

Best Practices

Set expectations.

Users should have a clear understanding of what value a product offers them, and what steps are necessary to accomplish their goal.

Use conversational language.

Robotic or highly technical language creates a barrier between the user and the experience.

This is especially true in potentially frustrating situations, such as error messaging. A friendly, conversational voice reassures the user that a solution is within reach.

Use plain language.

Plain language takes your audience’s current level of knowledge into account. It means knowing the expertise and interest level of the average reader, and avoiding technical terms and jargon.

If a technical term is absolutely necessary, and your audience is likely to be unfamiliar with the term, define it. Otherwise, plain language keeps your writing understandable and accessible.

For more on plain language, check out plainlanguage.gov, a site dedicated to keeping written content easy to read, understand, and use.

Be consistent.

Don’t use synonyms when creating instructions or interface labels.

Labeling a button “Next” in one step and “Continue” in another will cause confusion and impede progress towards their goal.

Embrace progressive disclosure.

Present the most important concepts or information first.

If written content is not immediately relevant, consider reserving it for a hidden panel or secondary screen.

Show, don’t tell.

Including relevant imagery, illustrations, or iconography can clarify your text and reduce the amount of writing needed to explain a concept.

items.title: Drafting a Case Study
items.content:
Getting Started

Writing a case study for your design portfolio can feel a bit overwhelming, particularly if you’re not used to reflecting upon and writing about your own accomplishments.

Depending on the specifics of the challenges you faced, the audience you’re speaking to, and the nature of the story you wish to tell, every case study might look a little different from one another. However, drafting responses to the following questions might get your story going, as these are examples of content many design portfolio case studies have in common.

As you begin drafting your responses, don’t worry about getting the wording right or being concise with your ideas just yet. You’ll revise for clarity in a later stage. For now, it’s most important to get your ideas down, and paint a thorough picture of the journey your selected project went through.

Introduction

  • What was the name of the company, product, or service?
  • What was your role on the project?
  • What was the main problem you were trying to solve?
  • What was one major insight, takeaway, or impact from conducting the project?

These last two answers are meant to provide a hook to interest the reader in your story. You’ll provide more detail in later stages.

The problem

  • What problem were you trying to solve on this project?
  • Was the problem clearly defined, or did you perform problem space research?

Users

  • Who was your target audience?
  • What work did you do to ensure you were aiming at the correct audience?
  • What deliverables document your user research or your understanding of user needs?

Ideation and testing

  • What ideation process did your designs go through?
  • How did you test the effectiveness of your designs?
  • What were the results of those tests?

Final design solution

  • What was the final result from your project?
  • How did you measure the impact of your solution?

Takeaways

  • Did you achieve your main goal of this project?
  • What was the greatest success of this project?
  • What is the most important lesson you learned during this project?
  • What next steps would you recommend for project stakeholders?

Write with the door shut

When drafting your case study, it’s best to initially write as much as possible, without worrying about the effectiveness of the writing. Stephen King calls this “writing with the door shut”.

With the door shut, downloading what’s in my head directly to the page, I write as fast as I can and still remain comfortable....

If I write rapidly, putting down my story exactly as it comes into my mind, only looking back to check the names of my characters and the relevant parts of their back stories, I find that I can keep up with my original enthusiasm and at the same time outrun the self-doubt that’s always waiting to settle in.

Stephen King, On Writing

You’ll have time to revise your writing, and to accept feedback from instructors and peers. But don’t do that now.

Gather as much material and written notes as you can, and answer the questions above thoroughly. You’ll go back and edit your responses later.

items.title: Voice and Tone
items.content:
Effective content is shaped heavily by voice and tone.

When a brand speaks with an inconsistent voice, users notice.

Consider the visual and verbal language associated with a high-performance athletic brand like Nike.

Nike shoppers expect aspirational imagery and text that take athletic achievement seriously.

If a Nike ad were to adapt the quirky, irreverent humor of a Skittles ad, the result would be like an actor breaking character. The content no longer feels authentically Nike’s, and audience no longer believes the scene.

But effective UX writing depends on a thoughtful application of both voice and tone. What’s the difference between the terms?

Voice is consistent.

Voice reflects a brand’s personality, and should remain consistent across platforms and experiences. Creating a brand’s voice requires a thorough understanding of your target audience, and their emotional associations with your products and services.

Establishing voice as part of a brand’s style guide helps keep communication with users sounding authentic, personalized, and natural. Brand voice establishes a relationship with users, and conveys a philosophy, attitude, and purpose.

Mailchimp’s Content Style Guide is an excellent example of a design system defining clear rules for applying brand voice to UX writing.

When we write copy:

We are plainspoken. We understand the world our customers are living in: one muddled by hyperbolic language, upsells, and over-promises. We strip all that away and value clarity above all. Because businesses come to Mailchimp to get to work, we avoid distractions like fluffy metaphors and cheap plays to emotion.

We are genuine. We get small businesses because we were one not too long ago. That means we relate to customers’ challenges and passions and speak to them in a familiar, warm, and accessible way.

We are translators. Only experts can make what’s difficult look easy, and it’s our job to demystify B2B-speak and actually educate.

Our humor is dry. Our sense of humor is straight-faced, subtle, and a touch eccentric. We’re weird but not inappropriate, smart but not snobbish. We prefer winking to shouting. We’re never condescending or exclusive—we always bring our customers in on the joke.

Tone is contextual.

The tone of UX writing, on the other hand, conveys mood, and should be adjusted based on context and the user’s emotional state. If Mailchimp wants to warn users about a serious security issue, humor isn’t the best way to get that message across.

Think about your own interactions with family, friends, and colleagues. Your personality doesn’t change much from day to day, as it’s shaped by your own principles and experiences. However, you adjust the words you choose and the way you say them based on context. Imagine comforting a friend who seems nervous or upset. That’s a different tone than one you’d use to chat with someone relaxed and smiling.

“Are you going to ask your boss for a raise in the same manner you’d ask a friend to go out for drinks? Probably not. Similarly, in an app, you won’t speak the same way when your user is concerned about entering their health details as you would when you congratulate them on making a purchase.” – Merav Levkowitz, Frontitude

Map tones to emotional states

One effective method for getting tone right is to map out different scenarios in which you expect to encounter users. Arrange descriptions of the user’s emotional state on a scale, from most satisfied to least satisfied.

Then, with your brand’s voice guidelines handy, determine how your brand’s tone would adjust to provide the appropriate response to the user’s situation.

The impact of tone of voice on user behavior

In 2016, Nielsen Norman Group published the results a of a tone of voice study comparing sample website content featuring the same presentation, topic, context, and details, while changing only the tone and the name of the organization.

Based on user feedback from the study, Nielsen Norman Group determined a number of key findings.

  • Trust and credibility are essential. When a web user encounters an unfamiliar brand, they make snap decisions on the authenticity, trustworthiness, and security of the brand’s website before deciding to continue. But users don’t really know whether the company is legitimate, or whether the website is secure. They’re forming a gut reaction based on a perception of trustworthiness. That perception can be heavily influenced by the right tone of voice.
  • A playful tone won’t work for everyone. Depending on the circumstance, a friendly or irreverent tone can actually undermine user perceptions of trustworthiness and professionalism.
  • A serious topic doesn’t require a cold and formal tone. Even traditionally dry industries like finance can benefit from conversational language. Users respond better when they feel brand communication comes from a human being.
  • Humor is risky. While humor can be a powerful way of differentiating you from competitors, failed attempts at humor annoy and alienate users. Test humorous messaging first, and don’t let a humorous tone interfere with communicating with users.

items.title: Revising your Case Study: Storytelling
items.content:
Revising with visual storytelling in mind

When drafting your case study, you gathered as much material relevant to your project as possible. However, we’ve learned in previous lessons that web users spend most of their time scanning web content, rather than reading it.

This is doubly true for hiring managers checking out case studies. Hiring managers have a lot of applications to review, so you’re lucky if they’re even reading your overview carefully. Most likely, they’re scanning the page quickly to get a sense of what your deliverables look like and whether your skills match their needs.

When revising your case study draft, concentrate above all on the parts of the page that would capture someone’s attention when scanning:

  • Headings and subheadings
  • Images and captions
  • Data visualizations
  • Pull quotes from users

Applying Freytag’s pyramid

In a previous lesson, you’ve encountered Freytag’s pyramid, a 5-part dramatic structure for effective storytelling.

With that structure in mind, here’s one possible technique for revising your case study for more effective storytelling.

Review the exposition.

In the introduction to your case study, make sure all of the following are clear:

  • What is the project?
  • What was your role?
  • What problem were you trying to solve?

Any text from the introduction that doesn’t help answer the above questions and set up context for your project should be discarded.

Review the rising action.

Study all the content between the exposition and the climax.

With each piece of content, ask yourself is this relevant in leading users from the exposition towards the climax? If not, rework or discard it.

Review the climax.

Make sure your case study features one standout moment, something a hiring manager will remember later. This could be

  • An unexpected insight that led to a new direction
  • A tough decision, and the technique you used to make that decision
  • A novel idea or solution to the problem

If your case study features no obvious climax, rework it until it does.

Review the falling action.

The falling action will likely be significantly shorter than the rising action. Your content following the climax should lead users to your resolution.

If your climax involved an exciting new insight or change in direction, it’s possible you needed to back up a bit in your design process and create more iterations. Even so, the content in your falling action section should serve to prepare readers for your conclusion.

Review the resolution.

Make sure your case study has a memorable ending.

  • What was the final outcome?
  • What impact did your work have?
  • What did you learn from conducting this project?
  • What next steps would you recommend?

The resolution should be fairly short, and the takeaways obvious to the reader.

items.title: Revising your Case Study: Making Edits
items.content:
Keep explanations meaningful

When explaining your design process, a heading and a photo of the deliverable isn’t enough. You’ll need to accompany your photos with meaningful details. Not a lot of details, but just enough to answer the following:

  • What did you do?
  • Why did you do it?
  • What was the result?
  • What did you learn?

Let’s keep these points in mind as we look at some examples.

⛔ Bad example: We conducted usability tests on our client’s landing page.

This is an inadequate description, because it only answers what you did. It neither explains why nor reflects on the results.

⛔ Bad example: We conducted usability tests by placing our client’s landing page in front of representative users. We used the concurrent think aloud protocol, inviting users to continuously verbalize their thoughts while exploring the landing page.

This example doesn’t actually provide reasons for conducting the usability test. It simply restates the definition for this step in the design process.

This kind of writing fails to consider your audience. As hiring managers and design team leaders are already familiar with usability testing and thinking aloud, there’s no need to define these practices.

✅ Better example: Our hypothesis was that a more prominent Call To Action would lead to more conversions on our client’s landing page. During usability tests, 60% of target users successfully proceeded to the signup form, a 30% improvement over the previous design. From the unsuccessful tests, the most common feedback was that the Call To Action was labeled unclearly.

This example provides the reason for conducting the test, the results of the test, and an insight gleaned from the results.

Increase visual hierarchy

One way to test the initial impact of a design is to perform a 5 second test. Give a test participant five seconds to review your design, then ask them what they remember. If the answer is different than what you expect, you’re either highlighting the wrong information, or too much content is competing for their visual attention.

If your most important content or messaging isn’t standing out, try either or both of the following:

  • Increase visual emphasis on your most important content.
    • Increase scale
    • Make text bolder
    • Surround with more white space
  • Decrease visual emphasis on less important content.
    • Decrease scale
    • Use lighter text weight
    • Move farther away from important content

Omit needless words

“Vigorous writing is concise. A sentence should contain no unnecessary words, a paragraph no unnecessary sentences, for the same reason that a drawing should have no unnecessary lines and a machine no unnecessary parts.” – William Strunk, Jr., The Elements of Style()

In Steve Krug’s web usability textbook Don’t Make Me Think, author Steve Krug presents his third law of usability in a chapter called “The Art of Not Writing for the Web”:

Get rid of half the words on each page, then get rid of half of what’s left.

Review your case study writing carefully for opportunities to remove unnecessary words. Following Krug’s rule, edit ruthlessly. If a word doesn’t get straight to the point, or if a sentence or phrase doesn’t contribute to the story you’re telling, toss it out.

Create scannable blocks of text

While you’re reviewing your text for needless words, keep an eye out for an opportunity to break longer chunks of text into shorter, more digestible pieces.

  • Use shorter paragraphs. Breaking a longer paragraph into two increases scannability.
  • Use bulleted lists. Rather than including key insights or ideas in the middle of a paragraph, break them into a bulleted list. Put the most important thought in bold text.

Visualize your data

We’ve learned previously that presenting raw data to your audience isn’t very compelling. When presenting to an audience, your goal is to transform that data into meaningful insights. What impact did those numbers have on your team’s decision making? What insights came from gathering qualitative data?

The same concept applies to case study design. It isn’t enough to simply present a table full of disorganized numbers or responses you’ve gathered. What impact did your data have in shaping your project? How can you make that story visual?

items.title: Designing Your Portfolio
items.content:
Showcase your work

“If I wanted to prepare myself as a candidate, my focus would be on having a really solid portfolio. It’s the best way to tell the story of your work and the impact you’ve had.” – Anna Rowe, UX Design Portfolio Advice from Hiring Managers

Your portfolio is one of the first touchpoints hiring managers have with you. It is the medium in which they understand in greater detail your skills and contributions.

Your portfolio is an opportunity to express your personal values and brand, but never at the expense of the end goal: showcasing your work. Your case studies demonstrate your approach to the design process and are assets and tools to get you an interview and ultimately a job.

Spark interest

First impressions are especially important when reviewing design portfolios. Most hiring managers scan your work and dig deeper only if it impresses them or piques their interest.

Think of organizing your portfolio as an additional opportunity for good user experience. Make sure the entry point is welcoming and provides the right context for the reader.

When designing your portfolio, ask yourself the following questions:

  • Who am I as a designer?
  • What are my passions and values?
  • Where am I applying?
  • Where can I leverage my personal brand in my portfolio?
  • How can my case studies highlight my design abilities?
  • Who is my audience, and what story should I tell them?

Content first

Though the design of the portfolio should make a good first impression, decorative elements are far less important than the content itself. Don’t let the design or your personal brand overtake the actual content of your portfolio. It is the case studies themselves that ultimately will contribute to the hiring manager staying longer than a quick scan.

Hiring managers generally on average spend 2-5 minutes on each portfolio and review approximately three pieces of work. If you muddle your portfolio with elements that distract from your strongest attributes, you may lose opportunities.

Note that minimizing decorative elements also speeds loading time. The slower your content loads, the more users bail out, especially on mobile.

Optimizing your images for the web will also lead to faster page loads.

Show process and impact

“Designers who highlight the challenges they overcame, lessons they learned, and why they chose their approaches tend to impress hiring managers the most.” – Ignasi Boza, Craft an Outstanding UX Portfolio With These Recruiter Tips

Your portfolio shouldn’t consist solely of deliverables. On each project, someone quickly scanning their eyes over the page should be able to get a sense of

  • Your process. How did you arrive at these deliverables? What validation did you receive from users?
  • Your impact. Did your project help users achieve their goals? What about improving business conversions?
  • Your learnings. What would you do differently next time?

items.title: MVP: The Minimum Viable Portfolio
items.content:
What belongs in a portfolio site?

There are four major parts of a portfolio site:

  1. The home screen
  2. Bio/personal statement
  3. Your case studies
  4. Your contact information

Note that this doesn’t mean your web portfolio will consist of four separate pages. Your personal statement will likely be featured on your home screen, while your contact information might be found on the header or footer of each page rather than on a separate page. And you’ll more than likely devote one page to each case study.

Together, these four sections form a Minimum Viable Portfolio: just enough to potentially spark the interest of hiring managers.

The home screen

While no two portfolio home screens are exactly alike, you’ll likely find at least some of the following:

  • A welcome to readers.
  • An action you’d like readers to take, such as visiting a certain page or contacting you.
  • An introduction to your design background or methodology.
  • An impressive visual to demonstrate your capabilities or introduce a case study.
  • A menu of options for navigating the portfolio.

Bio/personal statement

Your personal statement is meant to briefly introduce you to readers, and briefly summarizes your experience, goals, and values. Many design portfolios feature a personal statement prominently on the home screen.

You might include a lengthier bio elsewhere within your portfolio site. If you’ve had a particularly interesting journey leading to your current role, or wish to discuss outside passions or interests, this is the place to do it. However, keep in mind that hiring managers scanning your portfolio won’t read this content.

Case studies

Case studies are the primary reason visitors come to your site, so make sure they’re easy to find and reachable in as few clicks as possible.

When visitors browse your content, make sure your most impressive case study is nearest the top of the page or is visually most prominent. Hiring managers may only check out one project, so make sure it’s a meaningful one.

Contact information

Simple and direct is best. Most vistors will be interested in either your email or your LinkedIn, so make sure both addresses are easy to find. You might include additional social media if your posts are relevant to your professional practice.

A submission form isn’t necessary, and in fact adds extra work for the user.

MMVP: Mobile Minimum Viable Portfolio

Yes, hiring managers look at your site on a mobile device. But not for the reason you think.

They generally don’t use mobile as their primary way to view the details of your portfolio. But it’s likely they check out your site on mobile to make sure your content is legible, and nothing looks broken.

Companies need designers to know how (or be ready to start) to design on both desktop and mobile. So this is seen as a good baseline test of your ability to pay attention to details and design thoughtfully.

Always be aware of what happens when viewing the mobile version:

  • Images scale down and remain visible.
  • Images and text don’t get covered up or cropped.
  • Body copy text forms a single column, extending across the mobile viewport.
  • Modules of content rearrange in the proper reading or viewing order

items.title: Personal Branding
items.content:
More than just a logo

Your personal brand is about establishing who you are, what you have to offer and the emotional reaction you want your target audience to feel upon encountering all the visual and written assets you’ve created.

Your brand is what sets you apart

Focus on what you are genuinely great at and build your brand around that value. What qualities set you apart from other designers and would be attractive to the audience you would want to speak to? Your personal brand should speak to your strengths.

Your personal brand can be an extension of your personality. Are you detail-oriented? Are you bright and extroverted? Are you an efficient researcher? Start with making a list of adjectives or phrases that describe you, along with a list of the aspects of design you feel most passionate about.

Who needs personal branding?

Your personal branding is ultimately secondary to the actual contents of your portfolio. While a visually appealing personal brand is helpful, hiring managers visit your site to check out your case studies and skill sets. Your personal brand should complement your design projects without pulling attention away from them.

This is particularly true if your choice of specialization is something other than visual or UI design. Hiring managers will take the personal branding of a UI Designer more seriously than the personal branding of a UX Researcher or UX Designer, since the skills involved in building a personal brand have more in common with the daily tasks of a UI Designer.

If you’re a designer who’s never done any visual design or logo design, don’t start trying to master this craft now. You’ll find that logo design can be quite difficult, and a visually weak brand can end up hurting how you look to hiring managers. Beginners are better off sticking to simple design choices for personal branding.

Work with a color palette that reflects your personality and complements your design work without creating visual noise. A font pairing resource like Fontpair or Typewolf can help inspire typography choices for your logo, headings, interface elements, and body copy.

While typeface choice can express your personality as a designer, your text above all needs to remain legible at a variety of screen sizes.

items.title: Personal Statements
items.content:
What is a personal statement?

Your personal statement is a succinct, sincere distillation of your career and life to date, which points the way forward to your career as an emerging designer.

Your personal statement gets adapted into a few forms:

  • The “about me” section of your portfolio site
  • Your LinkedIn summary
  • Much of the content of your cover letters
  • Your summary on your resume

What makes an effective personal statement?

Your personal statement should be:

  • Short. Tell your story in as few words as possible.
  • Meaningful. It must read as highly personal and sincere.
  • Aspirational. It positions you as excited to start your new career and hopeful about future steps.
  • Flexible. Your personal statement gets adapted in multiple ways, for multiple audiences.

Your personal statement has two audiences.

You always have two groups of people who look at your personal statement.

  • Active audience. This audience consists of people you’ve sent to your site or who otherwise are interested in learning more about you.
  • Passive audience. This audience consists of people who stumble upon your site or who don’t yet know you. You have the opportunity to turn them into your active audience.

You have to write your personal statement to both audiences because both are interested to learn about you.

Your personal statement is not your bio.

Personal statements are based on your aspirations—what you plan on doing with your career in addition to some factual information about your abilities. It’s intended to be your best written first impression.

This is the clearest distillation of your professional values, written for a public audience of people who want to reach you and a more direct audience of people you want to reach. That means creating a list of your personal values will come in handy in crafting your personal statement. What matters to you as a designer?

items.title: Launching Your Portfolio
items.content:
Selecting a domain name

The first step in launching a portfolio site is selecting a domain name.

A domain name consists of two parts: a name and an extension, or top-level domain.

The two most commonly used extensions by designers are

  • .com
  • .design

You’ll want to choose a straightforward, memorable domain name, so if yourname.com or yourname.design is available, that’s a solid choice.

Use your preferred name: if you want to be called Chris, don’t register Christopher. And including your middle name in the domain name is probably advisable only if you commonly use multiple names (like James Earl Jones or Joyce Carol Oates) or include your full name in all your branding.

If your name combined with .com or .design isn’t available, try exploring other extensions:

  • .me
  • .work
  • .info

Again, strive for the simplest possible option. Complicating your domain name by adding numbers or using an alternate spelling makes your portfolio harder to find.

Choosing a web host

A domain name isn’t enough. You’ll also need web hosting, which is a service that provides web server space for you to upload website files that can be visited by the public.

Developers typically purchase web hosting and use a process called FTP, or File Transfer Protocol, to transfer web files from their computer to the web host’s server space.

However, designers often lack the coding expertise to build a website using HTML, CSS, and JavaScript, and need to look for another option.

Website builders

Website builders are platforms that aim to help users compose a website by using pre-built components or widgets. Many offer drag and drop functionality as well as pre-designed templates in which to start from. This means designers can create a website without having to write a single line of code, although some website builders offer the ability to update the code by hand if you’re comfortable doing so.

Website builders frequently provide web hosting. For example, all Squarespace plans include hosting for your site as well as unlimited file storage and unlimited bandwidth (a term meaning the maximum amount of data transmitted over an internet connection in a given amount of time.)

Below are a few popular examples of website builders.

Squarespace

Squarespace comes with a 14-day trial, but requires a monthly subscription once the trial expires. Squarespace’s website building tools allow designers to drag-and-drop content like text, images, and videos without directly editing code. Squarespace templates are responsive by default.

Squarespace is a more structured editor than Wix, meaning you can’t just drop an element anywhere. Your content will automatically snap to a grid. This creates more professional looking layouts by default, but could possibly frustrate designers seeking more precise control.

Squarespace offers fewer templates than Wix, though the design quality tends to be higher and better curated.

Wix

Wix is free to use, although removing Wix ads from your portfolio site will require upgrading to a paid plan.

The Wix drag-and-drop website builder offers designers the ability to start from scratch with a blank template, or to begin with a template created by Wix designers.

Designers looking for more precise control over their responsive designs can check out Editor X, an advanced Wix tool that offers more thorough CSS and JavaScript functionality.

Webflow

Webflow is free to use, although acquiring a custom domain and expanding beyond 1 GB/month bandwidth requires upgrading to a paid plan. Webflow is a platform that advertises complete freedom for the designer. It’s a more sophisticated web builder, embracing the full complexity and power of web development.

Webflow refers to creating layouts using its website builder as “coding visually”. In other words, working with Webflow more closely resembles coding with HTML and CSS, and allows designers to directly apply modern layout tools like CSS Flexbox and Grid.

Webflow offers designers fewer limitations and more precise control over their layouts than Squarespace or Wix, but at a steeper learning curve.

items.title: Project Brief: Build Early Money Habits
items.content:
Project Background

Build Early Money Habits provides age based, interactive money lessons for children 10 -12 years old (5th and 6th grade). It is a 5 week interactive live course taught online via Zoom where children learn about personal finance. Parents pay a one time fee to enroll the children.

The course covers the following topics:

  • Money 101: How we started using money and how it looks in different parts of the world
  • Saving & Budgeting: How you can help your future self
  • Our Economy: Making a lemonade stand
  • Stock Market: How others can help grow a lemonade stand
  • Compound Interest: How money over time can help grow a lemonade stand
  • Entrepreneurship: The basics of starting your own business

Parent Attributes

  • They have at least one child who is between the ages of 10-12 or +/- 1 year.
  • They are currently working towards a financial goal (saving for retirement, emergency funds)
  • They may be thinking about providing or have been asked by their child for an allowance
  • They are based in the US only
  • They are either renting or owning a home
  • (ideally) They will or intend on leaving an inheritance for their children
  • Disqualifiers:
    • Parents who are professional financial advisors
    • Non-US based children
    • Non English speaking children

Client-provided research

Age demographics

According to Jean Piaget, a renowned psychologist, children are learning reasoning between the ages of 7-12. Their cognitive development focuses on external events, logic and reasoning. At the ages of 10-12, they have a higher concentration and focus. The focus is on children in the US as the curriculum is geared towards the US markets and systems. This is a 25M population size that is expected to stay relatively stable over the next 10 years (US Child Population.

The value of learning about personal finance early

There are 5 key reasons to have children learn about finance.

  1. “Low financial literacy is correlated with a host of negative credit behaviors, including higher borrowing rates, mortgage delinquency, and home foreclosure.” Financial education is taught by the time habits are already set in adulthood, which is too little, too late (Brookings Institute).
  2. According to Forbes, 50% of children surveyed wish their parents taught them more about money.
  3. Nearly 25% of adult Americans state they didn't receive any education on money topics by their parents (CreditCard.com Poll).
  4. Online free information about money and investments is in bits and pieces. It requires a significant time commitment from parents to take abstract financial concepts and put them into easily digestible, age appropriate information.
  5. According to FINRA Investor Education, Americans' investment knowledge is low. This is especially true for women, where 40% demonstrated lower investment knowledge (GLFEC).
“Our findings provide hints for future directions for improving financial education. Perhaps future education should teach soft skills like propensity to plan, confidence to be proactive, and willingness to take investment risks more than content knowledge about compound interest, bonds, etc.” – Hader, Sood, and Fox 2013

See also:

  • 13th Annual Parents, Kids and Money Survey by T.Rowe
  • How To Build Habits

Requirements

Safety information

Since parents will naturally be concerned about the safety and security of both their own information and that of their child, it’s critical to communicate the following:

  • Children and parents will strictly have educational content. No advertisements and no advice on portfolios, companies, financial products, taxes
  • Data will not be sold to third party
  • No actual investing nor opening accounts will occur in the course

Terms to avoid

The client is providing financial education only. It’s equally critical to avoid using any of the following terms:

  • Advice - “we provide financial advice for families with kids”
  • Guarantee - “we guarantee your education will make you more money”
  • Financial Planning - “through this course you will have a financial plan”
  • Percent or Dollar Returns - “through this course you can expect 20% returns”

The Challenge

Build Early Money Habits is currently lacking a brand identity and digital experience for parents to learn about the program, sign up their children for a course and receive any educational resources. The children are lacking a digital experience to onboard the program and get their first lesson on Money 101.

Your Assignment

Given the limited time frame within which to complete this project, you’ve been asked to choose a specialization. Choose from only one of the following three approaches:

  • Research
  • UX
  • UI

To make your decision, read each of the three project briefs carefully, and decide which of the three aligns with your passions, your strengths, and the needs of your design portfolio.

items.title: Project Brief: Research
items.content:
Project goal

Your client has performed initial research on how to define and market a specific value proposition: offering live online classes to educate children ages 10-12 about personal finance. Your task is to not only continue that initial research, but also to come up with a research strategy for understanding the mindset and behaviors of consumers within the client’s target audience.

Your work on this project consists of two phases.

  1. In the first phase, you will conduct discovery research, with an end goal of presenting insights and recommendations to your client. The discovery phase should consist of problem space and market research. Feel free to recruit and interview participants within the target audience if it helps create a solid foundation of discovery research.
  2. In the second phase, you will craft a research guide outlining a clear and cohesive research strategy for the client to act upon. The research strategy should create clear goals for the research, propose methods for conducting research and gathering data, and supply interview questions and task scenarios for participants.

You will conclude your project by creating a client presentation to deliver both insights and recommendations from the discovery research phase as well as an overview of your proposed research strategy.

Research questions

Note: these research questions have been provided by the client. You are welcome to use them as a starting point in forming your own research questions.

  • What are the top pain points that inhibit parents from providing consistent education on money topics?
  • If parents had the option of sending their kids to a virtual summer camp about money habits,
    • What would they want their kids to learn and why?
    • How would they (parents) want to be involved?
  • What do they wish for their kids to know about money?
  • What topics are their children currently interested in?
  • How and where do they like to consume information? Who are their top influencers?

Requirements

This research project has one required deliverable: a comprehensive research guide detailing all of the following:

  • Research Objective
  • Research Questions
  • Research Methods
  • Participant Criteria
  • Interview Script

Note that the research guide isn’t meant to inform your own discovery research, but rather to use insights from your own discovery research to outline a plan for the client to embark on a clearly defined research project.

Possible additional deliverables

Unlike previous projects where you’ve been assigned to create specific deliverables, you’re in charge of providing additional outcomes for this project. While the client has provided a list of possible deliverables below, this is only meant as a starting point in determining your own deliverables.

  • Personas
  • Survey for client to send to customers
  • Insights + pain points
  • Competitive audit: Who is already providing this information, what are the gaps in their information and the needs/pain points of parents
  • Keywords and gap analysis for SEO
  • Analogous research of top content strategy executed by companies
  • Recommended business metrics
  • Recommended marketing tools: what tools should be used and how should they be measured? Ex: Newsletter w/number of subscribers, open rate and click through rate.

Project schedule

In addition to deciding what deliverables to submit at the end of the project, you are also taking on the role of project manager for this assignment. It’s up to you to create a schedule for your project, as well as to determine a midway point. What milestones will you have reached by the middle of your project? These milestones will comprise your Module 14 assessment.

You’ll need to set up a project management document to define and track progress towards milestones. This might best be accomplished using a Kanban-style task management application such as Trello.

Final presentation

In addition to conducting discovery research, crafting a research guide, and creating any other deliverables you find appropriate, your final submission must include a slide presentation designed to share your discovery findings and research strategy with the client. Don’t forget to

  • Open your slides by discussing the goal and motivation behind your research project.
  • Create visuals that highlight your most important findings or insights from any discovery research conducted. Don’t just present raw data.
  • Present an overview of materials intended to be distributed among user research participants. Explain the goals of using these materials to collect data from users.
  • Present any other deliverables intended to help your client better understand the target user or competitive space.
  • Conclude your presentation with actionable recommendations. Your conclusion should inspire questions or spark discussion.

items.title: Project Brief: User Experience
items.content:
Project goal

Your goal for this project is to create a responsive wireframe for a website for parents to learn about and sign up for a course designed to build early money habits for children ages 10-12. The client has requested that the website include at least the following information:

  • What similar products exist in the same market space? How do competitors establish trust or fail to establish trust with parents?
  • What do parents wish their kids knew about money?
  • What are the top pain points that inhibit parents from providing consistent education on money topics?

Final presentation

In addition to conducting appropriate market research, conducting a thorough information architecture and information design process, and creating any other deliverables you find appropriate, your final submission must include a slide presentation designed to share your research strategy with the client. Don’t forget to

  • Open your slides by discussing the goal and motivation behind your project.
  • Create visuals that highlight your most important findings or insights from any exercises or tests involving users. Don’t just present raw data.
  • Justify any information architecture or information design decisions, particularly if validated by user feedback.
  • Present an overview of design iterations, while concentrating your presentation on the final deliverable.
  • Discuss accessibility features. How can your interface be used by those who depend on assistive technology?
  • Conclude your presentation with actionable recommendations. Is there a step in the design process that should follow your presentation? Your conclusion should inspire questions or spark discussion.

items.title: Project Brief: User Interface
items.content:

Final presentation

In addition to conducting appropriate market research, conducting visual explorations and iterations, and creating any deliverables you find appropriate, your final submission must include a slide presentation designed to share your design solutions with the client. Don’t forget to

  • Open your slides by discussing the goal and motivation behind your project.

  • Communicate visual style requirements and rules for implementation.
  • Discuss accessibility features. What guidance are you providing to make sure your designs are implemented in an accessible manner?
  • Present highlights from any deliverables created.

items.title: Planning a Project
items.content:
Before getting started

You’ve been handed a design brief and you’re preparing to kick off a project.

Regardless of whether your role focuses on UX research, UX design, or UI design, you might feel tempted to jump right in and begin interviewing users or creating rough sketches. This feeling can be particularly strong if you’re working with a limitation such as a tight timeline or budget.

But immediately producing deliverables is a waste of energy if you don’t first take the time to fully understand the needs of the project and create a plan of action. In the words of Jeff Sullivan at Usability Geek,

You might think (the reasons UX projects fail) are rooted in poor communication. Stakeholders fail to communicate their vision, and designers fail to show stakeholders what the project can acheive.

But if you dig deeper, you’ll realize that this communication gap actually stems from poor planning. Neither stakeholders nor designers can be expected to fully understand the final vision for something as fundamentally iterative and expansive as a UX project.

Before you start thinking about deliverables, you need to analyze the materials your team has been provided with, and ask yourself the following:

  • What information do I currently have?
  • What information do need to know?
  • What is my plan for gathering the information I don’t have?

Ask the right questions

Before you begin thinking about project deliverables to produce, or even creating a strategy, take a closer look at the materials you’ve been provided with.

Take notes on the following questions. If you have an opportunity to check in with project stakeholders to receive further clarification, do so.

Project background

  • What problem is the product solving?
  • What is the main problem this project should solve?
  • What research or data do we have access to?
  • What approaches have been tried before?
  • How can we measure the success of the project?

User goals

  • Who is this product for?
  • What are their needs?
  • What are their goals while using the product?
  • What has worked well for them in the past?
  • What are their pain points?

Business goals

  • What is the organization’s business model?
  • What is known about the product domain?
  • How have competitors approached the same problem?
  • What are the business goals of the project?
  • What metrics can measure the success of the project?

Project scope

  • What is the timeline for this project?
  • What is the budget for this project?
  • Are there technology constraints?
  • Are there risks or challenges facing the project?
  • What should be considered outside the scope of this project?

items.title: Specialization: UX Research
items.content:
What is a UX researcher?

A UX researcher specializes in the research aspect of product design. UX researchers focus on gathering in-depth insights about users, focusing on understanding user behaviors, needs, motivations, and pain points.

What does a UX researcher do?

UX researchers focus on discovering how users think and behave given a particular context, problem, or challenge. They gather insights through questioning users and observing user behavior. UX researchers then synthesize research data into insights, and communicate those insights to teammates and stakeholders alongside actionable recommendations.

A UX researcher’s daily tasks might include

  • Identifying and prioritizing research questions and objectives
  • Developing research plan
  • Recruiting users for research studies
  • Analyzing and synthesizing research data to create insights and actionable recommendations
  • Presenting design research findings

What goes in a UX research portfolio?

A UX research portfolio tends to be process-oriented. How did you understand a given problem? What methods did you use to better understand user needs and behaviors? How did you convey those findings meaningfully to teammates and stakeholders?

UX research portfolios tend to highlight the following:

  • Problem space research. How did you determine your problem statement?
  • Discovery research. What initial research was necessary before determining a research plan?
  • Research methods. What methods did you use to better understand user needs and behaviors? How did you gather relevant users?
  • Insights. What key findings came from gathering research data? How did you communicate this information to stakeholders?
  • Outcomes. What recommendations did you present based on your findings? What impact did these recommendations have?
  • Learnings. What assumptions were challenged by your research? What was the greatest success of your research project? What would you do differently next time?

TL;DR

When creating a UX research portfolio, use extra care in crafting an introductory overview at the top of each case study. Think of this as your TL;DR (too long; didn’t read) version.

Imagine a hiring manager or recruiter reading only this section. Would they still be able to understand

  • Your role on this team?
  • The key problem you were trying to solve?
  • The impact your research had on the overall project?

If not, rewrite until this information can be quickly and clearly understood.

items.title: Specialization: UX Design
items.content:
What is a UX designer?

While the responsibilities of a UX designer will vary based on the needs of an individual company, UX designers are typically less focused on conducting research than a UX researcher, and less focused on visual design than a UI designer.

Instead, a UX designer focuses on making products and technology that are usable, enjoyable, and accessible for humans. UX designers focus on the journey the user takes through a product, and think about how the experience of using the product is structured to facilitate the user’s journey.

UX designers advocate for the user, keeping the user’s needs, preferences, and abilities in mind at all times. At the same time, UX designers need to consider business goals, and weigh whether a particular solution is technologically viable and beneficial for stakeholders.

What does a UX designer do?

As UX designers are expected to empathize with and advocate for the target user, UX designers are likely to conduct some research. However, research insights are frequently provided by those who specialize in UX research. UX designers use an iterative process to turn those research insights into potential solutions they can prototype and test on users.

A UX researcher’s daily tasks might include

  • Information architecture
    • Content audits
    • Card sorting
    • Sitemaps
  • User personas
  • Content development
  • Prototyping
    • Low fidelity/paper prototypes
    • Mid fidelity/wireframes
    • High fidelity/mockups
  • Usability testing
  • Heuristic evaluations

What goes in a UX Design portfolio?

A UX Design portfolio should demonstrate a clear understanding of an iterative design process. With each iteration, it’s important to demonstrate

  • The problem you were trying to solve
  • The hypothesis behind your potential solution
  • The results of testing your solution on potential users

Since UX Designers are responsible for both addressing user needs and meeting business objectives, case studies should conclude by emphasizing measurable benefits a solution provides for both users and stakeholders.

items.title: Specialization: UI Design
items.content:
What is a UI Designer?

A UI (User Interface) Designer focuses on the visual language and identity of an application, website, or program. Colors, spacing, typography, button styles, interaction states, and animations are all the responsibility of the UI Designer. UI Designers also create low, mid, and high fidelity prototypes for testing users.

UI Design can be viewed as a subset of UX Design. User Interface often comes after much of the User Experience work is accomplished, and focuses specifically on creating useful user interfaces rather than a consistent experience across products, interfaces, and services.

What does a UI Designer do?

User Interface Designers create the screens that users move through to reach an end goal, and create the visual and interactive elements that enable this movement.

This means that UI Designers need to be aware just of visual theories, such as color, typography, responsive design, UI patterns, and Gestalt principles. UI Designers also need to empathize with the user and understand the user’s mental model. What does the user expect will happen in a given circumstance? How can we design an interaction that matches that expectation?

A UI Designer’s daily tasks might include

  • Designing and annotating individual screens
  • Creating responsive designs
  • Designing buttons and creating various interaction states
  • Creating color and type palettes
  • Creating animation
  • Establishing style guides
  • Communicating accessibility requirements
  • Communicating with developers
  • Creating prototypes for testing in low, medium, and high fidelity

What goes in a UI Design portfolio?

A User Interface portfolio highlights completed design interfaces. However, screenshots of finished products and links to finished products or polished prototypes aren’t enough to create a compelling portfolio or land a job as a designer. The process of arriving at the finished solution needs to be as transparent as possible.

Storytelling

Your UI Design case studies should tell a complete story.

  • State the problem. What issue were you trying to solve? How did your potential solutions relate to that problem?
  • Show sketches and wireframes. What exploratory work did you create? How did you test these solutions? What did you learn from each test?
  • Show an evolution. Design is an iterative process. How did your thinking evolve over time? What did you learn that caused this evolution?

If you’re having trouble answering this final question, cast a spotlight on your struggles and moments of growth.

  • What were the toughest decisions you made?
  • What were some tradeoffs you made? No design solution is ever ideal. Demonstrate an awareness of the pros and cons of each approach, especially when that awareness is backed by data and testing.
  • What surprises did you encounter? Did any usability test results or user feedback surprise you? How did this change the direction of your overall project?

items.title: Overcoming Impostor Syndrome
items.content:
What is impostor syndrome?

Impostor syndrome is a psychological pattern in which individuals have difficulties recognizing their achievements and live in constant fear of being exposed as a fraud.

Impostor syndrome in beginners

“It’s natural to feel insecure when you’re a beginner surrounded by experts. We must become comfortable with the discomfort of being a beginner.” – Vivienne Kay, senior product designer, Shopify

Beginning designers often struggle with comparing their work and accomplishments unfavorably against more senior coworkers and peers.

As a junior designer, it’s important to compare yourself to people in the industry at the same level as you, rather than to senior designers. If you’re surrounded by experts who can mentor you, that’s a lucky position to be in and a great learning opportunity. Just remember that even subject matter experts started as intimidated beginners earlier in their career.

Impostor syndrome in design professionals

“I think it’s so easy to catch the feeling of imposter syndrome in the design industry because of how fast it moves. New tools come out regularly, there are new design-thinking processes to use; it can be so hard to keep up. If I don’t try and master that new thing, am I falling behind?” – Nancy Nguyen, Product Design Team Lead at Voices.com

Unfortunately, impostor syndrome doesn’t disappear as designers become more established within the industry. It’s still easy to measure yourself against the accomplishments of others, and against the skills you haven’t acquired yet.

To combat impostor syndrome later in your career, it’s important to remember the following.

  • Find a design community that discusses impostor syndrome openly. It’s easy to feel alone, but nearly every designer experiences impostor syndrome at some point.
  • Define self-improvement on what you want to do, not on what you perceive the industry wants from you. It’s impossible to acquire every skill. Are you learning a new technique or a new piece of software because it matters to the type of work you want to do, or because you’re worried about keeping up with other designers?
  • Celebrate your successes. Don’t get hung up on an A-minus grade, or a glowing performance report with a small critique. Take pride on your achievements, and reflect on how far you’ve come from wherever you started.
  • Learn from your mistakes. Failure is part of the design process. We learn, iterate, and move forward. Perfectionism is unachievable, and chasing it stunts your growth as a designer.

Impostor syndrome in underrepresented communities

It’s hard to feel like you belong in your industry when you see few faces like yours. Communities such as Women Who Design, Blacks Who Design, and Latinxs Who Design provide opportunities to share your story, offer and receive support, and expand your design network.

items.title: Crafting Your Elevator Pitch
items.content:
The 30-second elevator pitch

It only takes about two minutes to ride an elevator, so if you find yourself in one with a potential employer or investor before their time is up-- you have exactly 30 seconds to make your case for why they should hire or invest. Make sure your elevator pitch catches and keeps the attention you deserve.

The goal of a 30-second elevator pitch is to successfully communicate who you are, what you do, and what you want to do, quickly and effectively, with people who don't know you.

For a product designer, a successful elevator pitch should communicate all of the following:

  • Your passion. What is your why?
  • Your background. What were you doing before you got into Product Design?
  • Your motivation. What are you looking for? Why are you interested in Product Design?
  • Your strengths. What do you do well?

Structure of an engaging elevator pitch

Your present

Who are you right now? What is your professional tech identity?

Hi, My name is _______. I am a Product Designer.

Your past

What is your professional background? What is the catalyst or passion driving your career pivot?

I spent the past 5 years in marketing in the leisure travel industry, when I became fascinated by the work our data analytics team did; seeing how data informed our day-to-day strategy and priorities made me realize I wanted to be a part of that, and take my career that direction.

Your future

What are your career goals after Flatiron School?

I'd love to apply my business degree, marketing experience and data science skillset I built at Flatiron to help innovate travel startups understand their clients and provide once in a lifetime experiences.

Crafting your 30-second pitch

Attending tech community events, tech conferences, networking events, and job interviews, it is important to keep your introduction updated and have it ready when any of the following questions are asked:

  • “How did you get into [your field of study]?”
  • “What brought you to this conference/event?”
  • “Tell me about yourself.”

The following template can help you get your elevator pitch started.

Present: Introduction

“Hello, my name is _______________ and I am pursuing a career in _______________ while building my skills in _______________.”

Past: Challenges and opportunities

“In the past, I _______________ .”

“Throughout my career I’ve worked on a lot of projects, including _______________ .”

“I found a passion for _______________ while doing _______________ . ”

Future: Your ‘why’

“In the future, I’d like to take my experience in _______________ and my new skills in _______________ and do _______________ .”

“I have a specific interest in working with _______________ and I see myself on the trajectory within the next _______________ (timespan).”

“I am working on _______________ but I feel confident I’d be able to bring value to a _______________ position.”

items.title: Building Your Resume: Getting Started
items.content:
Traditional resumes vs LinkedIn

As you start putting your resume together, you’ll want to keep in mind two different potential ways of building and sharing your resume: LinkedIn, and a traditional print resume.

LinkedIn describes itself as the world’s largest professional network on the internet. LinkedIn is an incredibly important networking tool, and building your profile has much in common with creating a traditional resume.

While you’ll likely share your LinkedIn profile far more frequently than a traditional resume, employers may still request a single-page printable version of your resume. It’s important to have one prepared and to keep it updated for your job search.

Designing your resume

For the most part, designing your resume follows the same rules you would apply to any design deliverable.

  • Use a grid to arrange your content into precisely aligned columns.
  • Provide plenty of white space so readers can comfortably scan your content.
  • Use clear headings to name each content section.
  • Apply color sparingly and meaningfully. Print your resume in greyscale to test whether it remains legible.
  • Stick to a single page. LinkedIn resumes can be longer, but traditional resumes should be limited to one page.

Starting your resume

Contact information

Your contact information typically goes in the header of your resume. Your header should make the following clear:

  • Your name.
  • Your title. (e.g. “Product Designer”)
  • Where to view your work. This should be a clickable link to your online portfolio.
  • How to contact you. In most cases, your email address and phone number should be sufficient.

Summary

While a summary statement is an optional part of your resume, you might consider including one for two reasons.

  • As a designer who is new to the industry, your work experience may not yet speak for itself.
  • Summary statements are easy to customize. If you’re applying to a specific job listing, you can use your summary to highlight skills and traits that match the job requirements.

Tips for writing a strong summary statement:

  • Reference the job posting. Include the technical skills listed in the job posting or central to the type of role you’re seeking.
  • Make it personal. What are your passions? What separates you from other candidates? Your summary statement lets recruiters and hiring managers know what makes you unique, the same way a 30-second elevator pitch would.

items.title: Building Your Resume: Work Experience
items.content:
How to write about work experience

As a candidate that’s new to the industry, the most daunting part of creating your resume is probably the work experience section. How can you sound experienced when you’ve never worked a full-time design job?

When you’re getting started in the design industry, your experience listings likely fall into one two categories: design projects and work experience. In the 8-minute video below, UX and Product Designer Christine Chun describes the strategy for describing both on a resume that landed her a full-time design job straight out of bootcamp graduation.

Chun suggests that when your work experience is not design-related, list your design projects at the top so recruiters and hiring managers notice them right away.

Design projects

The design projects section of your resume includes any design work completed outside of full-time or long-term employment. This means student assignments, freelance work, and self-initiated projects taken on to thoughtfully practice and demonstrate your skills.

When starting out in the industry, it’s acceptable to describe the design projects you completed as a student on your resume. After all, those projects faced many of the same concerns as real-world design projects, and were taken through a similar design process.

However, in her article How to create a UX portfolio without UX experience, author Sarah Doody cautions against stopping there. Hiring managers and recruiters see a lot of portfolios from bootcamp grads, and reviewing the same projects over and over again gets a little tiresome.

Doody recommends becoming a problem spotter–in other words, someone who can observe an interaction and identify flaws in the experience.

The experience could be found within a digital product, but it doesn’t have to be. Spend time observing the world around you, and you might see users struggle to navigate physical spaces, enter or exit buildings, or pay for and board public transportation.

Doody notes that problem spotters don’t immediately attempt to find solutions, but concentrate first on discovering the “why” behind the problem.

In summary, including your school assignments is a great start, but your product design journey is far from complete upon graduation. Self-initiated projects are an excellent way to keep your existing skills sharp, build new skills, and distinguish your portfolio from fellow grads.

Work experience

The work experience section of your resume includes jobs you’ve done that are unrelated to product design. What work were you doing before you started at Flatiron School?

While it can be tempting to remove unrelated work from your product design resume, this is not advisable until you’ve gained some solid design experience. To succeed at any job, you likely made use of skills that would be valuable to an employer.

  • Communicating with others
  • Solving problems
  • Managing or leading a team

When writing about work expereince unrelated to design, your goal is to highlight specific, meaningful accomplishments that demonstrate you can be an effective worker and help a design team reach its goals. As Christine Chun says, “frame your resume in a way that connects everything back to your design skills.”

Formatting experience entries

Your experience listings should be presented in reverse chronological order, with the most recent experience nearest the top of the resume. Each listing, whether a design project or part of your overall work experience, should be formatted the same way.

  1. Name of the project. This should include the name of the client and your role on the project.
  2. Date and location. How long did you work on the project? Where did you complete the work?
  3. Descriptive bullets. Describe your contributions to the project:
    • What problem were you trying to solve?
    • What techniques or technologies did you use?
    • What impact did you have?

Tips for writing descriptive bullets

  • Each bullet point should begin with an action verb. Action verbs show readers you weren’t just “responsible” for a task. You applied your skills and accomplished something meaningful.
    • Conducted user research and interviews to improve key features such as their search system, filter options, and product location finder.
    • Implemented mobile marketing which produced 15,000 sign-ups and contributed 8% of total revenue.
    • Designed new user navigation and e-commerce platform, resulting in 20% increased revenues.
  • Your bullet points should be unique from project to project. Even if you used similar technologies or frameworks, each project is an opportunity to showcase different skills, features and functionalities.

items.title: Building Your Resume: Skills and Education
items.content:
Skills

The Skills section of your resume provides a snapshot of your technical capabilities. What parts of the design process do you excel at? What tools or software do you use that will impress potential employers?

Your list of skills should be easy to scan visually, so recruiters and hiring managers can look for terms that match their needs. You can help by grouping related skills into subcategories.

Your technical skills should include any skill you can speak knowledgeably about during an interview and could complete a technical challenge or assessment in. Again, don’t be afraid to update your list of skills based on the needs of a particular job posting, or to move the most relevant skills to the top.

Education

While employers want to see some form on education on your resume, the Education section should take up only a very small portion of the overall content. Include your time at Flatiron School on your resume, as well as any other work towards a certificate or college degree.

Education listings are typically limited to the name of school, followed by the degree or certificate earned, your major, and graduation date.
