items.title: Using LinkedIn
items.content:
Why use LinkedIn?

LinkedIn is a professional networking platform owned by Microsoft with over 400 million users that lets you post career updates, share content, and connect with people in your industry.

LinkedIn is one of the first results in Google when people search for you online, and the most common tool used by recruiters and hiring managers to review and connect with candidates.

If you don’t have a complete, optimized, and professional LinkedIn profile, you’re missing opportunities. These opportunities include those found in the hidden job market, a term describing jobs that aren’t advertised or posted online but instead found through networking.

LinkedIn benefits your professional career in 4 ways:

Professional credibility

A completed LinkedIn profile, full of keywords advertising your skills and aimed at the type of role you desire, builds your professional credibility and increases your discoverability for job openings.

Network building

LinkedIn makes it easy to connect with your existing peers and colleagues, to expand your network to include meaningful industry contacts, and to join discussion groups and follow influential organizations.

Being connected will help you understand what is happening in your industry and professional circle.

Research tool

LinkedIn is an important tool for researching the companies you’re interested in and preparing for interviews.

Job opportunities

Identify the skills most heavily sought by recruiters and hiring managers, find and apply to job listings, and receive notifications for new listings that match your strengths and interests.

Getting your profile noticed

For a LinkedIn profile to attract notice, it needs all of the following qualities.

  • Completeness. By completing 100% of your LinkedIn profile, you’ll achieve All-Star status. An All-Star profile is 40 times more likely to show up in a recruiter search than an incomplete profile.
  • Keywords. Search the job listings that appeal to you and take note of the skills, qualities, and descriptions that appear most often. Adding these keywords to your profile will make you more discoverable and will catch the eye of recruiters scanning your profile for a match.
  • Activity. Once your profile is complete, don’t let it sit idle. Seek new connections, leave supportive messages beneath other people’s posts, and–most importantly–post your own unique content.
    • Share your successes and recent projects
    • Post something you learned recently
    • Ask a question for discussion
    • Share and comment on an interesting article
    • Or even publish an article of your own!

In the following 20-minute video, DesignerUp instructor Elizabeth Alli shares her tips for creating a LinkedIn profile that will attract notice from UX, UI, and Product Design recruiters, hiring managers, and clients.

items.title: Building Your LinkedIn Profile
items.content:
Add a professional profile photo

Research shows that having a LinkedIn profile picture makes your profile 14 times more likely to be viewed by others.

Guidelines for choosing the right photo include

  • Choose a recent, high-resolution photo
  • Dress professionally, the way you would to work
  • Make sure you’re the only person in the photo
  • Your face should occupy at least 60% of the frame
  • Have someone else take the photo (no selfies)

Customize your public profile URL

LinkedIn allows you to make a custom URL for your profile, which looks more professional, adds legitimacy, and makes your profile easier to identify.

Your custom URL will look something like this: https://www.linkedin.com/in/yourname

Create your headline

Your headline is created when you add your positions to your profile. However, you can edit your headline to promote an area of expertise and let your personality shine through.

When you’re hunting for jobs, be sure to use a custom headline. An effective LinkedIn headline should

  • Advertise your skills and expertise
  • Communicate the value you bring to a new employer
  • Include keywords or phrases related to the type of job you want

Even if you’re currently between jobs, don’t include the word “unemployed”. Use the 220 characters in your LinkedIn headline to advertise your specific capabilities and the skills that make you stand out from the crowd.

Add contact information

You want to make it as easy as possible to get in touch with you. At the very least, populate the contact information fields on your profile with your

  • email address
  • online portfolio

You might additionally include other links related to your professional practice, such as blogs, social media, or GitHub if you’re a developer.

Write a summary

The About section of your LinkedIn profile serves as a maximum 2000 character summary you can use as an elevator pitch to introduce yourself.

  • Express your mission, motivation, and skills
  • Describe how you can benefit a company
  • Include keywords or phrases related to the type of job you want

Note that only the first 250 characters of your summary will display initially. The rest will appear truncated until the user clicks “show more”. Plan on capturing user attention with that first 250 characters.

Work and education experience

Your work and education listings on LinkedIn work pretty much the same as a traditional printed resume, with one exception. On a printed resume, you’re limited to a single page, whereas a LinkedIn profile has unlimited space.

This means that for your work history, you can include all your previous work experience, whether related to tech or not. All professional experience is real world experience, and succeeding at a job requires a combination of skill, determination, and communication. Profiles with multiple jobs actually receive up to 5 times as many views as ones featuring a single listing.

Just like on your printed resume, your bulleted points underneath each job listing on your LinkedIn profile should begin with an action verb, and describe

  • How you completed the task (including specific technologies)
  • Why you completed the task
  • What impact your participation had

Skills

A list of relevant skills on your profile helps you showcase your abilities, and helps others understand your strengths.

When thinking up skills to add to your profile, think not only of terms that match job listings you’ve seen, but also parts of the design process you’ve had practice with. Don’t be modest: profiles listing 5 or more skills listed receive up to 17 times more views and 27 times more appearances in search results.

Once you add your skills, your connections can endorse them. If someone endorses your skills, it will increase the likelihood of you being discovered for opportunities related to the skills you possess.

A good way to get endorsements for the priority skills is to send personal messages to colleagues, requesting an endorsement. It’s a quick request, can be completed in a minute, and works even better when reciprocal. (I’ll endorse your skills if you endorse mine.)

Recommendations

Recommendations are LinkedIn’s version of written testimonials. A thoughtful recommendation from someone within the industry can really make your profile stand out and demonstrate your strengths to potential employers.

Recommendations take more thought, time, and effort than Skills endorsements, so you’ll want to request them only from colleagues and peers you’ve formed a close relationship with. And again, don’t forget to write one in return.

Open to Work

In 2020, LinkedIn released a feature called Open To Work allowing recruiters and others in your LinkedIn network to see you’re seeking new opportunities.

By using this feature, you’re encouraging tech recruiters to reach out to you with job opportunities. However, before activating the Open To Work feature, make sure of two things:

  • Your profile is complete. Before you share your profile with recruiters, it should be thoroughly complete and the best possible representation of your current strengths and skills.
  • You’re not risking your current job. If you already have a full-time job, they might not be happy to discover you’re actively searching. While the Open To Work feature has a “recruiters only” option, LinkedIn can’t guarantee privacy from your current employer.

items.title: Networking Using LinkedIn
items.content:
Why is networking important?

As you start applying for jobs online, it’s important to recognize the amount of competition. There are often hundreds of applicants for a single opening. With so many applicants, your resume may never be seen by a recruiter.

In addition, many jobs aren’t even posted online and are found only through network. This is often described as the hidden job market.

By researching the companies you’re interested in, building relationships via LinkedIn connections, and conducting informational interviews, you can become the type of candidate people remember when job openings arrive.

Start simple

Once your LinkedIn profile is complete, the first and simplest thing you can do to expand your network is connect with people who already know you well.

Start by making a list of people you already know who might be on LinkedIn. While it helps if they’re in the design industry, they don’t have to be. Sometimes meaningful referrals and introductions come from friends outside the industry.

You might send connection requests to any of the following:

  • Family members
  • Friends
  • Coworkers
  • Classmates
  • Instructors

Sending a connection request to somebody you already know is a low-pressure activity. Depending on how well you know them, you may not even need to include a custom message with your connection request.

Networking events

Conferences, meetups, events, and seminars are great opportunities to not only learn something new about design practice, but also to expand your network.

  • You can use Meetup to receive notifications about in-person events in your area as well as virtual events related to your topic of interest.
  • A number of online resources list upcoming in-person and remote design conferences, including UIUXTrend.

Whenever you meet somebody new at a conference, meetup, or event, be sure to connect with them on LinkedIn. If it’s an in-person event, you can connect quickly using a QR code on the LinkedIn mobile app.

Otherwise, whenever you connect with someone you just met, be sure to personalize your connection request by including a polite reminder of where you met them.

Hi Bart,

It was great to meet you at the (Event Name) meetup! I’d love to stay in touch.

It’s a good idea to reach out to event speakers and organizers as well, even if you didn’t personally meet them.

Hi Lisa,

My name is Maggie and I attended your informative talk on inclusive research at the (Event Name). I learned so much I’ll be able to apply to my own practice! I’d love to stay in touch.

Brand new connections

If you admire the work of someone in the industry or view them as a potentially useful connection, it’s perfectly acceptable to reach out with a connection request, provided you keep a few things in mind.

Don’t be afraid.

As long as you keep your message polite, you’re not really bothering the other person. The worst that can happen is you don’t get a response.

Don’t take rejection personally.

Design professionals are busy. Some will respond to your connection request with a friendly message; some will accept your request but never write back; some you’ll never hear from at all. And that’s to be expected.

Do your research.

Your connection message should make it clear you’ve studied that person’s background and are impressed with some aspect of the work they do. Don’t hesitate to mention a mutual connection or a shared area of interest.

Always customize the connection request.

Make sure you given someone a reason why they should accept your invitation. If they are unsure who you are, and your invitation message is blank, the chances of them connecting with you is slim.

Don’t ask for too much.

It’s possible you’re hoping for more than a connection. If it’s a designer, perhaps you’d like an informational interview, or to ask them more about an article they’ve written. Or if it’s a hiring professional, maybe you want to ask them more about a specific role.

If that’s the case, be sure to stick to a single, specific ask. Make it clear how much of their time you’re asking for, and keep your request polite. You’re not asking for a job, but you might be forging a connection that could prove meaningful later in your job search.

items.title: Requesting an Informational Interview
items.content:
What is an informational interview?

An informational interview is not a job interview. In an informational interview, you ask questions of someone working in an industry, position, or company that you’re interested in. You will learn from their experience, while at the same time they’ll get to know more about your skills and ambitions.

When you’re requesting an informational interview, you’re not asking for a job. Think of it as an opportunity to strengthen your network, build a genuine relationship, and learn from someone who has succeeded in the industry you’re trying to enter.

An informational interview might take place in person over a cup of coffee, or as a 15-20 minute Zoom chat online.

Who to ask

Someone you know

It’s easiest to get a “yes” to a request for an informational interview from someone you already know. Also, following up with someone you’ve met at an event or a conference for an informational interview is a great way to stay in touch.

Ask your connections

If someone you know is connected to someone you’d like to speak with, ask for an introduction.

Someone you have no connection to

Reaching out to a LinkedIn connection you’ve never met for an informational interview is perfectly acceptable. It just takes a bit more preliminary work.

  1. Start by making sure your LinkedIn profile is complete and up to date, as they’re likely to look it over before responding.
  2. Research them online so you have a better understanding of who they are, what work they’ve created, and any writings or posts they’ve shared.

  3. Send them a request for an informational interview. Rebecca Beaton at LinkedIn suggests the following template:

    Hi [Name],

    My name is [first name] and I currently work at [place you work, if relevant]. I was browsing through LinkedIn and came across your information — I hope you don’t mind me reaching out of the blue here.

    [Then add something personal. E.g., “Your article/post about X/Y topic really resonated with me.” or “Of all the marketing managers I came across on LinkedIn, your profile stood out to me the most because ________”]

    I saw that you have extensive experience in [area you are interested in – be as specific as possible], and I’m very interested in learning more about that space. I would love to have the opportunity to run some questions by you, as well as tap into any advice you may have given your knowledge of the industry.

    I know that your time is extremely valuable so please don’t feel the need to respond in depth. If you do have 10 minutes to chat over the phone, or time to let me buy you a quick coffee, I would really appreciate it.

    Thanks in advance,

    [Your full name]

  4. Follow-up if you don’t hear back after one week.

During the interview

During the interview, you’re mostly there to listen. Take handwritten notes on insights you’d like to remember later.

You’ll certainly want to politely and thoughtfully respond to any questions they ask you, but the goal of the interview is to get the other person talking. Rachel Parnes at LinkedIn suggests coming prepared with the following questions:

  • What’s your biggest challenge in this role?
  • How do you see your job changing in the next 5 years?
  • What have you done that sets you apart from others in your career?
  • Is there something you wish you’d known or a skill you wish you’d had starting out in [fill in the industry]? Or Is there something you wish you had done differently starting out?
  • What is the best way for me to gain experience in your field, without taking major steps backward from the level I’ve achieved in my current career?
  • How does this company acknowledge the accomplishments of employees?
  • Do you have any words of encouragement or warning as a result of your personal experiences?
  • Is there anyone else you think I should speak to? (This is a great final question.)

It’s important to respect the other person’s time. If you asked for a 20 minute chat, start wrapping things up as 20 minutes approaches. Be sure to thank them for their advice, both in person and also with a thank-you email within 24 hours of the meeting.

items.title: Overview: The Interview Process
items.content:
Before Your First Interview

So you're interview for a promising product design job. Congratulations! Your resume and portfolio site are ready, but if you really want to maximize your chances of success, you will want to go further into your preparation.

As a Designer, you are never expected to be great at everything, but in an interview you want to be prepared to discuss anything. The hiring process is competitive, so it's important to stand out from the rest. Remember that hiring managers have very little time available for evaluating your portfolio before they make a decision on whether to pursue you as a candidate. In order to secure an interview, the best thing you can do is to make it easy on us to see how awesome you are.

Step 1: Introduction

Your resume and portfolio are the ultimate design challenge. The purpose is to give the hiring manager and recruiter enough signal, as quickly as possible, that your design skills and experience are a match for the role they’re trying to fill. They are also assessing how clearly you communicate the context around your work and how polished the overall presentation is.

The strongest candidate

  • Presents a resume where form and function are in perfect harmony.
  • Communicates their skills, expertise, and interests clearly and succinctly.
  • Participates in the design industry and shares work and ideas they’re proud of.

Step 2: Recruiter Call (contract)

For contract-based work, the recruiter’s first job is creating a great candidate experience on this call. Your recruiter will work to understand your past experience, your ideal next role, availability for interviews, potential commute, salary requirements, and where you’re at in the process with other companies.

This will also be your first opportunity to get to know the potential client's business and internal workings. If you have a question about benefits, location, company structure, the product, etc. — this is the time to ask.

Step 3: Meet the Hiring Manager

This is likely the first time you’ll chat with them, and their job in this call is to get you excited about the role, and the mission and vision of the company.

Be prepared for questions such as

  • Tell me about yourself.
  • What are you hoping to do or learn that you couldn’t do in your past roles?
  • What are you looking for in your next role?
  • Why (this company) in particular? What stands out?
  • What do you need to know about (this company) and the role to decide if it’s a good fit for you?

Take advantage of this time to ask questions and get to know the hiring team. Take time before the meeting to think about what you really care about in a company and what your ideal role looks like.

The strongest candidate

  • Clearly and thoughtfully articulates what they’re looking for in their next role.
  • Asks multiple questions that dig below the surface of the job description, looking for a good fit.
  • Shows genuine interest in the company, and excitement for the specific job and opportunity.

Step 4: Portfolio Review

This is a critical stage. The typical ask is to share two or three projects you’re most proud of, that best represent your skills and experience as a product designer.

It’s not just your work that’s on display—the hiring manager is also looking at how you manage your time (45 minutes to completely run through–including time for questions!), how you organize and present information, how you tell a story, and how you help someone who has no prior context about the problem or the work gain a clear understanding.

The strongest candidate

  • Tells a story around their work, sharing context, their journey through the project, and tangible outcomes.
  • Stops at key points to solicit questions.
  • Budgets time for questions and discussion, so that the session can end right on time.
  • Designs the whole experience of the presentation.

Pro Tip: Grab a glass of water. Got stuck answering a question? Take a deep breath and drink some water. This will give you more time to get back on track.

Step 5: The Panel Interview

The panel interview is often your first opportunity to meet your team! You’ll meet the people you’d be working with, understand more about the team culture, and get a feel for what it’d be like to actually be in the team work environment.

Not only will you meet other designers, you’ll also meet cross functional partners from engineering and product too. Their job is to dig deeper into your skills and experience, and assess fit with the role and the job we’re trying to fill.

What to expect from a panel interview: Part of your interview process will be specifically focused on your skills—usually, through a conversation with 1-2 members of your interview panel at a time, who is specifically tasked with assessing your process. They will be looking for: objective evidence of your abilities.

Session 1: Product walkthrough with a PM

Team goal:

Go deep and give you a clear understanding of the company product and the business problems it solves.

Questions to know:

  1. “Tell me about a time you disagreed with a PM, or past Manager, that was especially difficult for you. What did you do to resolve the situation?”
  2. “Tell me about a time where you had to deliver something that was ‘good enough’.”

The strongest candidates:

  • Ask thoughtful questions with the aim of more deeply understanding the product, customer, and opportunity.
  • Actively participate in the conversation, and are not passively led.
  • Show what it would be like to work in a collaborative setting with you.

Session 2: Design thinking exercise with a designer

Team goal:

The purpose of this session is to assess how you approach problem solving and ideating with a teammate. This is less about getting “the right answer” and more about understanding your process and ability to ask questions, think quickly, and manage ambiguity. This is a collaborative exercise.

A practice prompt:

“We’ve been tasked with building a new product that reimagines the eSigning experience on mobile devices. Let’s work together to try to come up with a compelling prototype we can build and share with our initial customers for feedback.”

The strongest candidates:

  • Demonstrate natural talent in breaking down a big, ambiguous problem into approachable chunks.
  • Ask many clarifying questions before jumping to conclusions.
  • Collaborate with the designer, leveraging the partnership to do better work than either could do alone.

Session 3: Design implementation with an engineer

Team goal:

Designers and engineers work together very closely to create new benefits for our customers, and this session gives us a glimpse into how you collaborate with your technical partners and how you approach that critical relationship.

A practice prompt:

“Our engineering team is always looking for ways to improve our front-end development process, and we’ve been tossing around the idea of creating a design system in partnership with the design team. Can you help me think through the process and approach?”

Questions to know:

  • “Tell me about a time you struggled to work with an engineer on your team.”
  • “What’s something you recently learned from an engineer colleague that changed how you approach your design work?”

The strongest candidates:

  • Demonstrate experience solving problems alongside engineers with empathy and understanding for their needs, constraints, and skills.
  • Ask questions and attempt to understand the deeper context.
  • Collaborate with the engineer, leveraging the partnership to do better work than either could do alone.

Session 4: Operating principles

Team goal:

The design team isn’t looking for “culture fit”—they look at something called principles fit. What do you value? How do you make decisions? And do those align with company values.

A practice prompt:

“You’ll be asked to describe experiences that show how you’ve handled situations that put stress on our operating principles: Empathy, Pragmatism, Authenticity, Innovation, Teamwork, and Results.”

The strongest candidates:

  • Align well with our operating principles , and can demonstrate how their values have helped them make decisions or face challenges in the past.
  • Ask many questions to more deeply understand what Snapdocs values and how those values are tested.

Session 5: Wrap up with the hiring manager

Team goal:

You’re pretty much done. Ask or answer any final questions.

Questions to know:

  • “How did the sessions go? How are you feeling about (the company)?”
  • “What questions can be answered for you?”
  • “What stood out during your interview (good or bad?)”

The strongest candidates:

  • Reflect openly about their impressions of the company and, if they’re interested, share excitement and reservations they have.
  • Reflect on the interview and provide positive or constructive feedback.
  • After the on-site, the interview panel will provide feedback to the hiring manager in private, and then discuss the feedback as a group.

items.title: Essential Interview Questions
items.content:
Types of Product Design Questions

During your interview, you may be asked questions of a few different types. These can be broken down into the following categories:

Situational

Situational interview questions are focused on how you would perform under certain circumstances while in your position as a product designer. They are similar in nature to behavioral questions.

Situational questions are meant to give your interviewer a feel for your on-the-job problem solving, along with the types of situations you anticipate. It's during these questions that you can provide past examples of exemplary work in your previous positions.

Design Challenges

Design challenges are often structured in a similar way. With these types of questions, you will be asked to pitch a product design based on some set of parameters given to you by the interviewer.

Some employers may even ask you to redesign something of theirs or some other famous product. All in all, the design challenge portion of your interview may be the most important for getting the job offer.

App/Product Critiques

App or Product Critiques are a bit more focused on your design philosophy and style. Your interviewer may ask more open-ended questions about an app or product of your choosing. Questions may range from what product designs you admire to pointing out major design flaws in an established product. The most common, of course, is about your favorite product.

You should come to the interview with some products already in mind.

Sample interview questions

We created a list of 8 product design interview questions, including questions from real companies, so you can nail your soon-to-come technical interviews.

Design Heroes

“Who are your design heroes? What are your favorite apps?”

Listening to the reasons why you love your design heroes and favorite apps can reveal a great deal about your everyday approach to product design. It sheds light on your “design thinking” sensibility and your bar for quality, and speaks volumes about what kind of product designer you are.

Design Thinking

“What does the term ‘design thinking’ mean to you?”

The term “design thinking” is often synonymous with human-centered design (HCD). The interview listens for you to describe “design thinking” as a user-centered design process. Most of all, it’s a “people-first” approach—a design process mindset that designs products around people’s needs, motivations, and behaviors.

Users with Disabilities

“What is your approach to making websites and platforms accessible to all user groups, including users with visual, hearing, and motor disabilities?”

The interviewer intentionally takes notice of how aware you are and if you follow the World Wide Web Consortium’s ”Web Content Accessibility Guidelines.” Have you performed an accessibility analysis on a previous project?

Some examples of using accessibility could include using voiceover commands to navigate websites and apps for people with motor disabilities, adding captions to a video, which benefits people who are deaf or hard-of-hearing, making content easier to read by screen readers for the blind, or designing an option to use large typography for users with vision impairment.

Design Process

“Describe your product design process and what methods you follow.”

In general, good product designers will walk through a specific process (or “toolkit”) they follow when approaching a problem or project. It will likely be a set of steps they take to solve user problems and create engaging product experiences. The interviewer listens for a clear process and a goal to align with their company's needs and values, a deep curiosity and a constant desire to learn, and the specific steps you would take to solve user problems.

Key concepts or methods used to carry out this process may include but are not limited to: competitive audits, stakeholder interviews, user personas, empathy maps, user research, content audits, minimum viable product (MVP) and Lean UX, information architecture, business model canvases, mood boards, storyboards, use case scenarios and user flows, customer journeys, wireframes, mockups, prototypes, and usability testing.

A Great Designer

“What does it mean to be a great product designer?”

This answer helps the hiring manager know the type of product designer they are considering. While there is no right or wrong answer, a good product designer should have extensive knowledge about the product design process and possess a “design mindset.” A great product designer would talk about what a “design mindset” means, a comprehensive, holistic, end-to-end product design process, approaches, and methodologies. You should be willing to walk step-by-step through an ideal product design approach you consider essential to excellent product design and that guides your work toward robust working solutions.

  • The interviewer listens for humility backed by confidence.
  • The interviewer listens for answers that include a discussion around empathy

Design Trends

“What are some of the biggest trends in the product design field?”

A product designer who thinks ahead will be an invaluable asset to the company. The interviewer may want you to discuss new use cases beyond screens—or how designing for accessibility is an area of interest for you. In this question, you can discuss new prototyping tools that save developers and designers time by converting the design to code, or may explain an evolving trend and how terrific it is to be at the forefront of technology.

Whatever the answer, let your passion should shine through. In this question, it’s not about technology, it’s about solving problems for people in new and efficient ways.

Product Design Example

“Walk me through a product design example where you set out to solve a business problem.”

Using a case study, a great product designer would demonstrate their understanding of the difference between designing an interface, a website, or an app, and also a way to solve a business problem. It's best to talk about the discovery/problem definition phase, where you carry out comprehensive research to uncover insights into the source of the problem.

Next, keeping business goals in mind, you would research users from the target demographic and identified common themes, unmet user needs, and where the business may have fallen short in serving that demographic. You would demonstrate your skill at evaluating the goals of the company, the use case scenarios, and how to best align them to find a solution.

Lastly, you could reach into your product design toolkit and wireframes and prototypes (among other things) to explore potential product design solutions. Through user testing, you could have validate ideas and hypotheses focused on obtaining significant business values from the solutions achieved by optimal product design.

Product Design Project

“Describe a recent product design project you were particularly challenged by and how you approached the problem.”

Product designers thrive on solving challenges, so a good candidate would readily share enthusiasm about how they approach problems. This question helps the interviewers understand more about your process. What did you find challenging, and why? How did you set out to come up with a solution?

While there is no right or wrong way to approach a particular challenge, having a clear strategy to facilitate an end goal is essential.

items.title: Presenting Your Portfolio
items.content:
Describing your work

If your portfolio looks good, you have a great call, pass any mini design challenges and interviews with individuals go well, then you usually get invited to give a portfolio presentation. This can be your final chance to leave a positive impression on the team you may be joining. It’s equal parts art, science, and a little bit of serendipity. So how do you make sure your work shines and your presentations stay on point?

This part of your interview shows off a specific skill to your potential employer. How do you verbally describe your work to a room of people who’ve done similar work for a lot longer than you?

Presentation Outline

  1. Introduce yourself. Who you are, personally and professionally. And how your background made you the person you are today.
  2. Explain your process. How you approach design, and what you have to offer any company, not just this one.
  3. Explain your work. How you approached these projects, and how they made you grow as a designer.
  4. Synthesize. Make it clear that the combination of all these makes you the best person for this job.

Presenting your Portfolio: Dos and Don'ts

The portfolio presentation is an opportunity to show your best work and walk your panel through your design process. At most companies you’ll be presenting your work to 4-6 designers of all stripes (visual, interaction, product, junior to senior), plus or minus a few product or engineering counterparts. Be prepared to articulate your design thinking and defend your design decisions.

Do:

  • Pay attention to detail
  • Be selective
  • Be aware of the time

Don’t:

  • Talk too much about the overall product vision of a project. Focus on the nitty gritty design decisions instead.
  • Show too few visuals or too much polish. Don’t stick to the finished design. Show a spectrum of work that illustrates your design process and tells the story of how & why you landed where you did. Explaining tradeoffs and compromises should be part of the conversation.
  • Take all the credit. The bigger the project, the more likely it is that you didn’t do it all. Your interviewers know that! Give credit to those you collaborated with: Be transparent about which decisions you owned, and which you did not.

The Right Way to Pitch Yourself

Portfolios are attached to people. What would it be like to work with you, not just your designs? Expressing your personality, your level of interest in the company, and your work processes are essential to acing your interview. Here’s a quick look at how to present yourself in the best light possible:

  • Prep collateral in advance. Bonus points for videos and prototypes.
  • Acknowledge limitations. Before your panel can.
  • Show interest and curiosity in the company’s work. Relate your work to problem spaces the company operates in.
  • Share humor, humanity, and a realness. Show what it might be like to work with you.

Things to remember

The interview panel has likely already seen your case studies you made publicly available. They have a baseline knowledge of you already. Your job is to use this presentation to show a new side of yourself and your work.

The presentation of your portfolio is covering a lot of content. Because of this, your best chance to impress your audience is through your confidence and familiarity with the material you present. That requires significant rehearsal.

items.title: Tips for Design Challenges
items.content:
What are design challenges?

Design challenges are mini exercises that designers might do to strengthen or showcase their problem solving and design skills. Companies will often leverage design challenges to provide opportunities for skill-building and team building. It’s also common for design professionals to leverage them to sharpen their skills or add to their portfolios. But design challenges are probably most frequently encountered in design interviews.

Tech companies have slightly different approaches to interviewing for Product Designer positions. But all of them aim to check candidate’s product thinking. Design challenges are a way to get signal on skills that aren’t always evident in a portfolio: problem solving strategy, product thinking and scope analysis, communication, collaboration, prioritization.

Design challenges are an opportunity to more authentically share and reflect on your problem solving process. You can explore the problem however you want, and the solution doesn’t have to be perfect or ideal because you’re not expected to get it right anyway, your solution isn’t going to get built.

Types of design challenges

Design challenges vary in length and scope. Some will be one hour, others can last a week. Some will be directly related to the company’s business or current projects. Others will be random or creatively unusual, and encourage you to generate out-of-the-box solutions.

Design challenges usually fall into two categories.

Whiteboard challenges

Whiteboard challenges are exercises that happen live, in the room with people from that company, with roughly executed deliverables thought out on the spot. You’ll often be asked to talk out loud while you sketch out your thoughts and ideas.

For remote interviews, an “onsite” challenge might happen over a remote collaboration tool, such as Miro or Mural. Or, the challenge might focus more on talking through your approach rather than visualizing it.

Take-home challenges

Take-home challenges are given at various stages in the interviewing process and are expected to be completed on a designer’s own time. Depending on the company, prompts will drastically vary in format, timeframe, and complexity.

While still very much about getting a sense of your design approach, take-home challenges are often leveraged to assess technical capability. For example, you might receive an assignment that requires the use of specific software or tools or that asks for a specific outcome, such as a prototype.

How to approach a design challenge

1. Understand the task

Before you do anything, you’ll need to get alignment and agreement on the task. If you have any questions about the challenge, ask questions before doing anything else. One question area you to get clarity on is the expected outcome of the challenge itself.

Pro Tip: Write down the agreed upon outcome in big letters so you can be reminded of it throughout the exercise.

Typically, for design challenges, you’ll have access to writing tools like sticky notes and paper or a whiteboard. You can create a bullet list of expectations and a high-level or stages for the challenge: define, understand, brainstorm, iterate and test, reflect.

2. Identify everything you know

When you first begin working on a design challenge, consider everything you can be fairly certain about and everything you don’t know but might be able to find an answer to during the challenge. Write everything asked and answered down. Make drawings if it helps.

Half the time you spend on the challenge should be asking questions, writing down assumptions, and aligning on definitions/goals with the other person in the room. You want to develop as clear an understanding as possible about what the problem is you’re attempting to solve, why it’s a problem, and what you might be able to do to resolve it.

Pro Tip: As you progress through a problem it’s vital to communicate your thoughts and rationale.

3. Begin exploring what you don't know

Focus on diverging ideas first by exploring the extreme ends of the landscape you defined in the previous stage: go as far into one extreme possible solution as you can, then jump to the other end of the spectrum and do the opposite. Repeat until you begin to formulate a more realistic vision of a possible solution.

Bring in the interviewer, if they are playing a collaborative role. Make the activity into a brainstorm and utilize the interviewer for feedback, for coming up with ideas, or for flagging things you might have missed (it’s totally ok to say: “What am I overlooking?” and “Does this feel like a good direction to you?”).

Remember to always tie what you’re doing back to the expected outcome of the challenge and the problem being solved.

If you’re drawing something on the board, explain why. If you’re going to ignore a potential problem or drawback to a solution, state as much (you don’t even need to explain why, this is all make-believe anyway and the goal is to progress toward solving a problem). Talk about your thinking, where you’re getting stuck, how you want to proceed. When in doubt, ask if you’re providing enough detail or if you need to be more transparent.

4. Reflect on the challenge

Allow a few spare minutes to take time to reflect out loud. Interviewers want to see self-awareness and reflection, as both are important traits of a good problem solver.

Things to remember

The design challenge is a highly condensed format of the day-to-day work you might do as a product designer, so nobody expects you to come up with an ideal solution.

The challenges you encounter are designed to be bigger than what you’re able to accomplish in the given time. That’s on purpose.

The goal is not always for you to finish; the goal is to demonstrate how you think and work.

items.title: The Ethics of Design Challenges
items.content:
Who benefits from design challenges?

As design challenges are becoming more of a staple in the design interview process, there has also been a growing conversation around the ethics of design challenges.

The most significant criticism has been towards companies who ask interview candidates to work on projects or problems currently being tackled internally. Designers should be wary of participating in spec work–that is, uncompensated design work performed as part of a design challenge or contest.

Another common criticism is whether design challenges are even a helpful form of assessment. This critique poses that while design challenges require a significant amount of additional work, they don’t usually provide any insight that wouldn’t be gained from a portfolio review and/or discussion of work.

Design challenges are borderline unethical.

We definitely should judge organizations that require them as being places we recommend professionals not consider applying to.

Companies post jobs should have to state whether they’ll require a candidate to do a design challenge.

— Jared Spool (@jmspool) October 27, 2020

Take-home challenges potentially introduce a lot of unfair advantages and disadvantages depending on a candidate’s situation. For example, a lengthy challenge might be doable for an unemployed recent graduate, but what about a single parent who already has a full-time job?

If a design challenge seems excessively demanding of your time, it’s worth reassessing whether this is still a place you’d like to work.

Assessing design challenges

Here are a few things to keep in mind when you encounter a design challenge while interviewing with a company.

Your time and talent are valuable.

Remember, you deserve to get paid fairly for your work.

Some companies offer to compensate designers for take-home challenges. If you’re asked to do unpaid work, consider whether the time and effort you’re putting in is worth it to you.

Make sure you’ve invested before committing.

Since design challenges are a significant time investment, they’re often reserved for later stages of the interview process when the company and candidate have gotten to know each other. If you’re asked to do a design challenge in early stages, you might first ask for an informational interview so that you can get a better idea of the role and expectations before committing to the challenge.

You shouldn’t be solving a current business problem.

“After a very enjoyable initial call where I had a great rapport with the interviewer, she explained that the next round of interviews was a design exercise: I was to redesign a section of their existing product. If the CEO liked it, I’d move on to the next round of interviews.”

Jamal Nichols, Unpaid UX Work Disguised As “Design Exercises”: How To Handle It

An ethical design exercise is one that can be completed in a reasonable amount of time and is unrelated to the company’s current needs. If you’re being asked to solve a company business problem, back away politely.

items.title: Next Steps
items.content:
🎉 You did it!

Congratulations! You’ve reached the end of Flatiron School’s Product Design program.

via GIPHY

As you review the work you’ve completed over the course of the program, take a moment to reflect on how much you’ve learned and how much you’ve grown.

Once you’ve graduated, spend a few days relaxing, doing something you love to do. You’ve earned it.

But after those few days have ended, be ready to get busy again. Because there’s work left to do.

Launch your online portfolio

Before you can launch your job search in earnest, you’ll need an online portfolio to share samples of your work with recruiters and hiring managers.

Over the upcoming weeks, plan on selecting a host for your online content. Most Flatiron grads choose a website builder such as

  • Squarespace
  • Wix
  • Webflow

Your minimum viable portfolio should be mobile-legible, and should include

  1. A home screen
  2. Bio/personal statement
  3. Your case studies
  4. Your contact information

Fortunately, you’ve already had one round of practice with the most challenging part of creating an online portfolio: drafting body copy and selecting imagery to tell the story of a single case study.

Build your network

Once your LinkedIn profile is complete, you should be working on expanding beyond your existing network.

  • Send out connection requests. These can be to people you already know, people you meet at events and meetups, or workers in the industry you’d like to know better.
  • Keep your profile active. Share updates, post interesting articles, and leave supportive comments on posts by people in your network. The more active your profile, the more it will attract notice.

Maintain your practice

Being a designer gets better with practice. And if you don’t maintain that practice, your newly acquired skills can grow rusty.

Spend time observing the world around you with a sketchbook in hand. Look for processes that could be streamlined, for experiences that could be improved, or for new ways of examining an old idea.

Self-initiated design projects are a great way to sharpen your existing skills, develop some new ones, and add to your portfolio and resume.

And self-initiated projects aren’t just for beginners. In 2011, a Greek design agency called Beetroot created a bestselling poster by using 55,440 red lines to illustrate the connections between occurences of the names of the protagonists in Shakespeare’s Romeo and Juliet.

The motivation for the poster? Beetroot experienced slow times and limited budgets following an economic recession of late 2009. Beetroot started a series of self-initiated projects to keep their portfolio active, and ended up winning Agency of the Year at the 2011 Red Dot Design Awards.

So keep an eye out for opportunities to learn, to practice, and to grow. You got this.
